Class ForecastWidgetModel

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.analytics.site.models.WidgetModel
      • io.analytics.site.models.LineGraphWidgetModel
        • io.analytics.site.models.ForecastWidgetModel
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IMetricDependent
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DataForecastModel

    public class ForecastWidgetModel
extends LineGraphWidgetModel
    Things that can be displayed/configured: -Date range, time span of range in milliseconds -Extent of forecast -Historical data points -Historical data points, smoothed -Forecasted data points, smoothed -Forecasted data points, with seasonality -(Planned) Forecasted data points, with noise Interacting with the ForecastWidgetModel: Update properties of the model, like:
    Author:
    Dave Wong

      • updateData

        public boolean updateData()
        TODO: REFACTOR!!! This is a huge mess. TODO: Replace Date with Calendar What are we doing here? -Figuring out what data we actually need, given information in the model. -Actually making a call to get the data. -Fetching the actual pertinent pieces of info/data from the API return for processing. -Collecting statistics and information about the data. -Generate the forecast and smoothed data sets. -Place all the data we have in variables to be accessed.
        Returns:

      • smoothData

        private java.util.AbstractMap.SimpleEntry<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Double>,java.lang.Double> smoothData(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Double> data,
                                                                                                   double alpha,
                                                                                                   double beta)
        Uses a two-pass double exponential smoothing algorithm to smooth out a set of data. The first pass may introduce lag into the smoothing, so the second pass goes in the reverse direction, reversing the lag. Since two passes are made, choices for alpha and beta values may need to be higher than they would for a single pass. This also updates a private member variable that stores the slope of the trend line generated at the end of the smoothing process. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_smoothing#Double_exponential_smoothing for more on double exponential smoothing.
        Parameters:
        data -
        alpha - Must be a double between 0 and 1.
        beta - Must be a double between 0 and 1.
        Returns:
        A SimpleEntry containing a smoothed data ArrayList as the key, and a double as the value indicating the slope at the last data point from exponential smoothing (this is important for forecasting).

      • updateForecast

        private java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Double> updateForecast(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Double> data,
                                                   int length,
                                                   double lastSlope)
        Updates the forecast we have saved, given a set of data. The option to present a particular set of data, instead of just the original data set member of this object, allows for creating a forecast from varying sets of data - perhaps even hypothetical. This assumes that the data provided is already normalized.
        Parameters:
        data - A normalized (free of seasonal trends) set of data to forecast.
        length -
        Returns:

      • getJSONPointsHistorical

        public java.lang.String getJSONPointsHistorical(boolean smoothed,
                                       boolean normalized)
        Formats the historical data points into an JSON array of objects with "date" and "value" properties. Note: If both smooth and normalized booleans are set to true, the data will be normalized first, and then smoothed (not the other way around).
        Parameters:
        smoothed - A boolean indicating whether the data should be smoothed or not.
        normalized - A boolean indicating whether the data should be normalized or not.
        Returns:
        A JSON array of objects with "date" and "value" properties.

      • getJSONPoints

        private java.lang.String getJSONPoints(long startDateTime,
                             java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Double> values)
        Formats a list of data points, given a start date, into an JSON array of objects with "date" and "value" properties.
        Parameters:
        startDateTime - The starting date which coincides with the first value in the list of values.
        values - The list of values.
        Returns:
        A JSON array of objects with "date" and "value" properties.
